title: Option to auto-select pasted content after pasting

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body: Type: Feature Request When pasting text into the editor (e.g., a Python block or paragraph), the newly inserted content is **not automatically selected**. This makes it inconvenient when users want to quickly re-indent, reformat, or wrap the pasted block, especially if the indentation is off or if additional editing is required right after pasting. **Suggestion:** Add a setting such as: ```json "editor.selectAfterPaste": true ``` When enabled, any content that is pasted (via keyboard or mouse) would remain selected immediately after the paste operation, allowing users to: * Quickly adjust indentation (e.g., with `Tab` or `Shift+Tab`) * Apply formatting or run commands on just the pasted text * Avoid manually reselecting the block that was just inserted **Why this matters:** * Improves workflow when dealing with multiline code snippets * Saves time in refactoring or formatting pasted blocks * Particularly useful in indentation-sensitive languages like Python or YAML VS Code version: Code 1.103.0 (e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f, 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Add "Select for Compare" and "Compare with Selected" options directly in file tab context menu

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-tabs
labels.description: VS Code editor tab issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body: Type: Feature Request 🔸 Description / Suggestion: Currently, to compare two files in VS Code, users must right-click the file name in the Explorer sidebar to access "Select for Compare" and "Compare with Selected". However, when multiple files are already open in tabs, this process is unintuitive and slows down the workflow. Suggestion: Add the "Select for Compare" and "Compare with Selected" options to the right-click context menu of file tabs (the tab bar at the top of the editor). This would allow users to initiate comparisons directly between open files without going back to the Explorer panel. Why this matters: Improves UX for users working mostly in the editor view Makes the compare workflow more discoverable and fluid Aligns with the principle of minimizing context-switching VS Code version: Code 1.103.0 (e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f, 2025-08-06T21:40:10.271Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

title: Copilot Pro can't access to  Anthropic Claude 3.7/4 Sonnet in VS Code
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: [Check in VS Code extensions panel]
- VS Code Version: 1.103.0 (user setup)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100
- Feature: Model selection in Copilot Chat
- Selected model: Only Claude 3.5 available (Pro subscription should include 3.7/4 Sonnet)
- Logs: [Please attach Copilot Chat logs from Output panel]

### Problem Description
As a Copilot Pro subscriber, I previously had access to Anthropic Claude 3.7/4 Sonnet in VS Code, but since August 6th (2025-08-06), the model selection has reverted to only showing Claude 3.5. Despite multiple attempts to manually switch or re-add the paid models, the functionality remains broken.

### Steps to Reproduce:
1. Have active Copilot Pro subscription
2. Open VS Code with latest Copilot Chat extension
3. Attempt to change model in chat interface
4. Observe only Claude 3.5 appears as available option

### Expected Behavior
Should maintain consistent access to Claude 3.7/4 Sonnet models as part of Pro subscription, matching web interface availability.

### Additional Context
- Regression: Functionality worked prior to August 6th
- Attempted solutions:
  - Multiple manual attempts to switch/add paid models
  - Verified subscription status is active
  - Confirmed web interface still shows correct models
- System Details:
  Commit: e3550cfac4b63ca4eafca7b601f0d2885817fd1f
  Electron: 37.2.3
  Chromium: 138.0.7204.100
  Node.js: 22.17.0

title: Fix OAuth redirect URI format to align with Microsoft's URL standards
body:
## OAuth Redirect URI Format Not Aligned with Microsoft's URL Standards

### Problem
VS Code's OAuth implementation generates redirect URIs without trailing slashes, while Microsoft's own OAuth 2.0 documentation and standards-compliant identity providers (including Entra ID) require trailing slashes in redirect URIs per RFC specifications.

This creates a mismatch where:
- **VS Code generates**: `http://127.0.0.1:3000`
- **IDP expects**: `http://127.0.0.1:3000/`

### Root Cause
Microsoft Entra ID (and other compliant IDPs) automatically append trailing slashes to redirect URIs during OAuth flows, following Microsoft's documented standards. However, VS Code's implementation returns URLs without trailing slashes, causing URI mismatch validation failures.

### Recent Change Context
A June 29th PR that modified `loopbackServer.ts` removed the trailing slash, introducing this standards compliance issue. This change made VS Code generate non-compliant redirect URIs that don't align with Microsoft's own OAuth 2.0 format requirements.

### Solution
This PR restores trailing slashes in two key locations:

1. **`loopbackServer.ts`** (line 105): Runtime redirect URI generation
2. **`oauth.ts`** (lines 739-746): Dynamic client registration redirect URIs

**Changes:**
- `http://127.0.0.1:${port}` → `http://127.0.0.1:${port}/`
- `http://localhost` → `http://localhost/`
- `http://127.0.0.1` → `http://127.0.0.1/`
- `http://localhost:${port}` → `http://localhost:${port}/`

### Impact
- Resolves OAuth authentication failures with "redirect_uri_mismatch" errors
- Ensures compatibility with standards-compliant OAuth providers
- Aligns VS Code with Microsoft's documented OAuth 2.0 URL format requirements

### Standards Reference
This change ensures VS Code follows Microsoft's own OAuth 2.0 redirect URI format requirements, improving compatibility with standards-compliant identity providers.

Fixes #260425

title: Keep activity bar icons visible and clickable at top/bottom to toggle sidebar

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: workbench-views
labels.description: Workbench view issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

When the activity bar is positioned at the top or bottom, keep its icons visible and allow clicking them to toggle the sidebar, matching the behavior of left/right positions.

## Current Behavior
- Left/Right activity bar:
  - Sidebar can be collapsed while activity bar icons remain visible
  - Clicking an icon opens/expands the sidebar; clicking the active icon can collapse it
- Top/Bottom activity bar:
  - Ctrl+B hides the sidebar but also hides the activity bar icons
  - Clicking icons does not toggle the sidebar

## Requested Behavior
- Keep activity bar icons visible when the sidebar is hidden, even with top/bottom activity bar
- Allow clicking activity bar icons to toggle the sidebar (open/close) and focus the selected view
- Preserve existing keyboard shortcuts (e.g., Ctrl+B) to hide/show the sidebar without hiding the icons
- Maintain consistent animations and focus behavior across all positions

## Benefits
- Consistent UX across all activity bar positions
- Better space optimization while retaining quick access to views
- Improved discoverability and usability with both mouse and keyboard

title: proposal: Standardized Location & Format for Agentic Toolkit Documentation (agents/*.md)
body:
Currently, agent/toolkit documentation for AI agents is fragmented, each provider uses different naming conventions, folder structures, and formats. This makes it harder for the community to share, extend, and integrate toolkits across ecosystems.

I propose adopting a common standard for storing these markdown files:
One folder, one .md per tool.
Suggested structure:

```
agents/
  WARP.md
  VSC.md
  CLAUDE.md
  ...
```

I believe for VSC it's currently `copilot-instructions.md`, I suggest it could be `agents/copilot-instructions.md` or equivalent.

PS. I have opened this issue in Claude-code, codex, and this repo

title: Feature Request: Improve Diff Review Workflow in Chat Panel (Auto-Clear / Session Diff / File Navigation)
body: ### 🧩 Current Limitation After multiple turns of interaction with the coding agent (e.g., refactor, fix, optimize), the **diff list in the chat panel keeps accumulating file changes**. This leads to a cluttered and harder-to-track review experience — especially in multi-step refactors involving many files. For example, after asking the agent to refactor a service class, then following up with more tasks, the file list keeps growing: --- ### ❌ Problems: 1. No option to **clear diffs** from the UI after reviewing them. 2. No ability to **see just the changes made in this turn** (diffs accumulate across turns). 3. Difficult to **track what has already been reviewed** vs what’s new. 4. You can’t diff the **entire session as a whole** or **diff between two specific turns**. --- ### ✅ Proposed Features Please consider adding one or more of the following: #### 🔘 Manual Controls * **“Clear Reviewed Files”** button to remove files from the diff panel. * **“Clear All”** to reset the diff panel manually between turns. #### 🧠 Smart Behavior * **Auto-clear reviewed files** after “Keep” or “Undo” is clicked. * Or, **group file changes by turn** and allow collapsing older turns. #### 📘 Advanced * **"Diff entire session"**: view all cumulative changes since turn 1. * **"Diff since last reviewed"**: keep track of last reviewed state and show what’s new since then. * **File filter/search** in the diff panel. --- ### 💡 Impact * ✅ Reduces cognitive overhead when reviewing multi-step changes. * ✅ Makes it easier to reason about the current vs previous state of the code. * ✅ Helps avoid accidentally missing or double-reviewing changes.

title: VS Code OAuth  Redirect URI Format Not Aligned with Microsoft's URL Standards

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version:  1.103.0 (Universal)
- OS Version:  15.6 (24G84) MAC

## Problem

  VS Code's OAuth loopback server generates redirect URIs without trailing slashes (http://127.0.0.1:port), while Microsoft's own OAuth 2.0 documentation and standards-compliant identity providers (including Entra ID) require trailing slashes in redirect URIs per RFC specifications.

  This creates a mismatch where:
  - VS Code generates: http://127.0.0.1:3000
  - IDP expects: http://127.0.0.1:3000/

  ## Root Cause

  Microsoft Entra ID (and other compliant IDPs) automatically append trailing slashes to redirect URIs during OAuth flows, following Microsoft's own documented standards. However, VS Code's  loopback server returns URLs without the trailing slash, causing URI mismatch validation failures.

  ## Impact

  - OAuth authentication flows fail with "redirect_uri_mismatch" errors
  - Affects any OAuth provider that enforces Microsoft's redirect URI format standards
  - Creates inconsistency between VS Code's implementation and Microsoft's documented requirements

## Environment
- VS Code version: 1.103.0 (Universal)
- OS: macOS (15.6 (24G84) 

## Labels
- bug
- oauth
- authentication
- vscode-extension

title: Feature Request: Allow Reviewing Code Diffs While Agent is Still Generating

labels.name: *out-of-scope
labels.description: Posted issue is not in scope of VS Code

body: ### 🧩 Current Limitation When using **Agent Mode**, after asking the agent to make changes to a file, the **code review panel is disabled until the generation is fully complete**: This leads to two key issues: 1. 🔒 You cannot **begin reviewing the generated diffs** while the agent is still working — even though parts of the edits may already be available. 2. 🐢 If you send a **follow-up prompt** before reviewing the current changes, the agent begins new edits on top of incomplete ones, and you **lose the opportunity to parallely inspect previous diffs** as the toolbar remains disabled. This slows down iteration speed and breaks the fast feedback loop that makes working with agents productive. --- ### ✅ Proposed Solution Enable the code review panel **as soon as partial changes are available**, even while the agent is still generating the full response. #### Suggested Behavior: * ✅ Allow reviewing diffs **incrementally** during generation. * ✅ Do not block the “Keep” / “Undo” UI until the full response is done — activate it as edits arrive. --- ### 💡 Impact * ✅ **Faster iteration cycles** — you can review and decide on early changes while the agent continues working. * ✅ Makes AI coding assistance feel more **fluid, interactive, and human-paced**.

title: Implement robust command re-routing system for terminal commands to native tools
body:
This PR implements a comprehensive system for re-routing terminal commands to more appropriate native tools in VS Code's chat interface, providing a better integrated experience and error handling.

## Problem

Previously, VS Code had limited command re-routing capabilities that were hardcoded for specific python/jupyter commands. Users running simple commands like `cat file.txt` or `mkdir newdir` would execute them in the terminal instead of leveraging VS Code's more integrated file operations.

## Solution

### Core Architecture

**CommandRoutingRegistry**: A new generic, extensible system for registering command routes with:
- Priority-based routing (higher priority routes take precedence)
- Regex pattern matching for flexible command detection
- Parameter extraction functions to convert command arguments to tool parameters
- Tool availability checking

### New Tools

**ReadFileTool**: Handles file reading operations (`cat`, `type`) with:
- Integration with VS Code's file service
- Proper error handling for missing files
- Formatted output with syntax highlighting context

**CreateDirectoryTool**: Handles directory creation (`mkdir`, `md`) with:
- Integration with VS Code's file service
- Cross-platform support (Unix/Windows commands)
- Proper error handling and user feedback

### Built-in Routes

- `cat <file>` → ReadFileTool
- `type <file>` → ReadFileTool (Windows equivalent)
- `mkdir <dir>` → CreateDirectoryTool  
- `md <dir>` → CreateDirectoryTool (Windows equivalent)

### Integration Flow

When a user types a command like `cat file.txt`:

1. `RunInTerminalTool.prepareToolInvocation()` calls the enhanced recommendation system
2. The new routing system checks for matching routes first
3. If found, returns a recommendation message suggesting the appropriate tool
4. The terminal command is not executed; the recommendation is shown instead
5. User can choose to use the suggested tool or re-run the terminal command

### Backwards Compatibility

The system maintains full backwards compatibility:
- Existing python/jupyter tag-based routing continues to work unchanged
- Commands without routes fall back to normal terminal execution
- Users can still force terminal execution after seeing recommendations

## Example Usage

```typescript
// Before: cat command would execute in terminal
// User types: "cat package.json"
// Result: Terminal output with potential issues

// After: cat command is routed to ReadFile tool
// User types: "cat package.json" 
// Result: "The terminal command 'cat package.json' could be better handled by the Read File tool..."
```

The system is easily extensible for future command types:

```typescript
CommandRoutingRegistry.registerRoute({
    commands: [/^ls\s+(.*)$/],
    toolId: 'vscode_listFiles_internal', 
    extractParameters: (commandLine, match) => ({ path: match[1] || '.' }),
    priority: 100
});
```

## Testing

Comprehensive test coverage includes:
- Unit tests for CommandRoutingRegistry functionality
- Unit tests for ReadFileTool and CreateDirectoryTool
- Integration tests validating the complete workflow
- Backwards compatibility tests for existing python/jupyter routing

Fixes #253884.

body: Type: Performance Issue I wrote my Java object oriented programing (oop) exam using VS code provide by my school, Robert Gordon University Aberdeen on August 5, 2024. I created a project folder and two sub-folders for my procedural and oop sections and manually saved them. Shortly before submission, I attempted to manually save my files using 'control + s'. To be double sure, I clicked on each file and selected the save option. To be tripple sure of saving my file, I proceeded to save the project file. When I tried to submit, I realised that my VS Code was unresponsive; frozen. I called for assistance and complained to the invigilator that my system was unresponsive. He simply opened files on the task bar and searched for my project file, then submitted on the submission platform without examining my froxzen vs code. To my greatest surprise, the folder turned up empty (contents not saved) on the exam drive despite my attempts to manually save my files. The schools systems manager claimed they had no issues with their operating and backup processes, no crash logs were found. I failed the course and the university has refused to acknowledge any technical or administrative error on their part. I would appreciate some technical background on whether this is a common problem with vs code and what could have happened to help me resolve this issue. Thank you. VS Code version: Code 1.92.2 (fee1edb8d6d72a0ddff41e5f71a671c23ed924b9, 2024-08-14T17:29:30.058Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22621 Modes:

title: Add Hello World extension to demonstrate basic VS Code extension structure
body:
This PR adds a complete "Hello World" extension to the VS Code repository to serve as a basic template and demonstration of VS Code extension development.

## What's Added

The new extension is located at `extensions/hello-world/` and includes:

- **Extension manifest** (`package.json`) with proper metadata, command contributions, and activation events
- **TypeScript source code** (`src/extension.ts`) demonstrating the activate/deactivate pattern
- **Command registration** that shows "Hello World!" message using `vscode.window.showInformationMessage()`
- **Build configuration** integrated with VS Code's gulp build system
- **Documentation** (README.md) explaining usage and development

## Extension Features

The extension registers a single command `helloWorld.helloWorld` that can be accessed via:
1. Command Palette (Ctrl+Shift+P / Cmd+Shift+P) → "Hello World"
2. Displays an information message saying "Hello World!"

## Technical Implementation

- Follows VS Code extension best practices with proper activation/deactivation lifecycle
- Uses TypeScript with full VS Code API type support via `src/vscode-dts/vscode.d.ts`
- Properly manages disposables for resource cleanup
- Compiles successfully as part of the VS Code build process
- Added to `build/gulpfile.extensions.js` compilation list for build integration

## Purpose

This extension serves as:
- A minimal working example for new extension developers
- Documentation of the basic extension structure and patterns
- A reference implementation following VS Code coding standards
- A starting point for more complex extension development

The implementation is intentionally minimal to focus on demonstrating core concepts without unnecessary complexity.

title: github.copilot.nextEditSuggestions.enabled not toggling with keybinding
body:
Sometimes nextEditSuggestions is on the right track, and other times, it suggests things that are completely off-base and/or destructive, and there needs to be an easy way to tell it `JUST STOP SUGGESTING FOR A SEC`. For this feature to be net-useful there really needs to be more control over when it comes into play vs. not

However, by default, enabling/disabling this feature involves a series of clicks. After binding the setting name `github.copilot.nextEditSuggestions.enabled` to a VSCode key combo, it gives this error message upon use:
```
command 'github.copilot.nextEditSuggestions.enabled' not found
```

title: Clean up auth provider account usage if extensions are uninstalled

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Issue identified by VS Code Team member as probable bug

labels.name: authentication
labels.description: Issues with the Authentication platform

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
I almost had this, but I had to partially revert code here:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/253690

Context:
* There are 3 things that could use an account: An extension, an MCP server, a built-in feature (like Settings Sync)
* They all use a specific authentication session (a token) that pertains to a certain account that is associated with an auth provider

The big idea is that usage information and access should be cleaned up when:
* an extension is uninstalled
* an MCP server is uninstalled/removed
* (optional) a built in feature is turned off

We do a good job at handling this for MCP servers because we have the following contribution:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/75d7429244bc453c46df77bd2544513f53298810/src/vs/workbench/contrib/authentication/browser/authentication.contribution.ts#L174-L214

But you'll also notice a similar change commented out for extensions:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/75d7429244bc453c46df77bd2544513f53298810/src/vs/workbench/contrib/authentication/browser/authentication.contribution.ts#L118-L172

Commented out temporarily due to the fact that this code has a bug. The intent of the code is:
* wait for extensions installed to be resolved
* if we have usage data for an extension that is no longer installed, remove it

But it seems like there's a bug here where it would remove all usage data... so perhaps there's a race condition. Looking at the code deeper, maybe these events were firing before extensions were resolved:
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/75d7429244bc453c46df77bd2544513f53298810/src/vs/workbench/contrib/authentication/browser/authentication.contribution.ts#L129-L133

or perhaps this is not the right code for getting the current state of all extensions available (note: available != activated)
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/75d7429244bc453c46df77bd2544513f53298810/src/vs/workbench/contrib/authentication/browser/authentication.contribution.ts#L151

anyway, there's still some work here to truly clean up auth provider data. Doing so will allow us to surface Sign Out (instead of Disconnect which would leave the account arround) buttons in the MCP picker which is a little smoother.

title: Lack of VS Code response to problematic extensions reported for years
body:
Type: Bug I reported a broken extension using the "Report Issue" feature in VS Code, selecting the extension as the cause. The problem is that this only creates an issue on the extension’s GitHub repository, with no follow-up or action from VS Code or the Marketplace. In practice, it’s useless: even if an extension causes serious problems for years and multiple users report it, nothing happens. The extension stays available, with no warning, and continues to affect the user experience. There should be a proper system in VS Code to report an extension directly to Microsoft or the Marketplace team — not just the extension author. That way, issues wouldn’t sit unresolved for 2+ years without any result. That’s why I’m classifying this as a bug, because it’s a serious and concerning problem on VS Code’s side. the extension is Python import helper issues: https://github.com/barnuri/vscode-extensions/issues on marketplace same problem 2 years ago: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Bar.python-import-helper&ssr=false#review-details VS Code version: Code 1.102.3 (488a1f239235055e34e673291fb8d8c810886f81, 2025-07-29T03:00:23.339Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:
